content.title: Vascular Behçet Disease
content.definition: Vascular manifestations of Behçet disease, a systemic vasculitis affecting vessels of all sizes characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. Vascular involvement (vasculo-Behçet) occurs in 7-38% of patients and includes both arterial aneurysms/occlusions and venous thrombosis, with arterial aneurysms being the leading cause of mortality.

epidemiology.geographic_distribution: Silk Road countries (Turkey, Iran, Japan, Korea)

unique_features.pe_rarity: PE is RARE despite extensive DVT

treatment_controversy.immunosuppression: May be more important than anticoagulation

vascular_evaluation.imaging: CT/MR angiography of all arterial beds

medical.anticoagulation: Controversial, often used for venous disease

learning_objectives: Recognize vascular manifestations of Behçet disease
Understand the inflammatory nature of Behçet thrombosis
clinical_pearls: PE is RARE in Behçet despite extensive DVT - thrombus is adherent/inflammatory
Pulmonary artery aneurysm with hemoptysis is characteristic (Hughes-Stovin syndrome)
NEVER operate during active Behçet - anastomotic pseudoaneurysm risk is very high
Immunosuppression may be more important than anticoagulation for venous disease
Think Behçet in young male from Silk Road country with recurrent DVT and oral ulcers
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Extensive DVT requires aggressive anticoagulation - Reality: In Behçet, immunosuppression is the priority
